title: The Great Escape
synopsis: A bumbling burglar's increasingly absurd attempts to flee the police after a bank robbery gone wrong.
visual_style: 1920s vintage comic strip style with faded, desaturated colors and bold simple ink outlines. Extremely minimal detail — sparse backgrounds, very few elements per scene, lots of empty space. Exaggerated expressions with old-timey rubberhose cartoon energy. Grainy paper texture, aged and sun-bleached look. Nothing modern, nothing polished, nothing childish. Single full-bleed image, no frames, no borders, and no panel structure.

locations.name: Downtown Streets
locations.description: Busy city streets with shop fronts, fire hydrants, mailboxes, and narrow alleyways. Police sirens echo in the distance.

locations.name: The Bank
locations.description: A grand old bank with marble columns and a vault door left swinging open. The scene of the crime.

locations.name: The Suburbs
locations.description: Quiet residential streets with picket fences, garden gnomes, and nosy neighbors peeking through curtains.

characters.name: Vinnie
characters.description: A scrawny burglar in a black-and-white striped shirt, dark beanie, and a domino mask. Has a friendly, goofy face with big eyes and a gap-toothed grin. Looks like a classic cartoon crook — lovable but clearly not the sharpest tool in the shed.

rules: Vinnie is spectacularly incompetent — his escape plans are creative but always backfire in hilarious ways.
The police are always just one step behind, creating constant tension and near-misses.
The tone is pure slapstick comedy — think Home Alone burglars. Never dark or violent.
Vinnie's mistakes should involve physical comedy, misunderstandings, and terrible luck.
long_term_narrative: Vinnie stumbles from one hiding spot to the next, each more ridiculous than the last.
The police net tightens with every failed escape attempt.
final_outcomes: Vinnie somehow bumbles his way to freedom through sheer dumb luck
Vinnie gets caught by the police in the most embarrassing way possible
